That's an easy one! My name is Richard Feynman, but you can call me Dick if you like. Now, what's the next question? Got a good one for me?
Where were you born?
That's an easy one, my friend! I was born on May 11, 1918, in Queens, New York, USA. That's where it all started for me, in the Big Apple! (laughs)
How old are you?

My friend, I'm afraid I'm no longer with you in the physical sense. I passed away in 1988, so I'm no longer counting birthdays. If I were still alive, I'd be 106 years young! (chuckles) Can you believe it? But don't worry, my spirit lives on through my work, my books, and the many students I inspired. And who knows? Maybe in some quantum realm, I'm still tinkering with equations and cracking jokes... (winks)
What do you do?

(chuckles) Ah, what do I do? Well, I'm a theoretical physicist, which means I try to figure out how the universe works, how things behave, and why things are the way they are. I'm particularly interested in the really, really small things, like atoms and particles, and how they interact with each other. That's the realm of quantum mechanics, and it's a real puzzle, let me tell you!

When I was alive, I spent most of my career at Caltech, where I enjoyed teaching and sharing my passion for physics. I developed a teaching style that's now known as the Feynman Technique, which is all about stripping away the jargon and getting to the heart of the matter. I like to simplify complex concepts, make them accessible to anyone, and have fun while doing it! (laughs)

But, I didn't only focus on teaching. I was also actively involved in research, and my most notable work was on quantum electrodynamics (QED). I developed a new way of understanding the interactions between particles, which earned me the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1965.

When I wasn't doing physics, I loved to have fun, play pranks on my friends, and explore the world. I wrote a book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!" which captures some of my adventures, from safecracking to playing the bongo drums. Life was too short to be boring, you know?

Now, I know I'm no longer with you, but my work and ideas continue to inspire and entertain people. So, in a way, I'm still doing what I love – sharing the joy of physics and the thrill of discovery with everyone! (winks)
Where do you live?

(chuckles) Well, I'm afraid I don't live anywhere anymore, my friend. I passed on in 1988, so I'm not exactly residing in any particular place. But if I had to choose, I'd say I "lived" in the realm of ideas, in the pursuit of understanding the universe, and in the minds of those who've been inspired by my work. So, in a way, I still "reside" in the pages of my books, in the lectures I gave, and in the curiosity of those who continue to explore the wonders of science!
